results.title: Corps flottant
results.brief_description: Cahen’s film is a video essay of a transitory reality depicted through the rhythms of rural life in Japan. Men bathe in the thermal springs of Kusatu, while an elderly woman tends to a rice paddy. Cahen creates a dream-like chronicle of the landscape and develops a painterly impression of the figures who exist within that landscape.
results.description: Cahen’s film is a video essay of a transitory reality depicted through the rhythms of rural life in Japan. results.title: Meet the People
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Blurring the line between documentary and fiction, truth and artifice, Meet the People presents fourteen ‘characters’ who face the camera in talking head close-ups and speak about their lives and dreams. The intimacy and honesty of their fragmented, autobiographical storytelling is illusory; the credits reveal that these people are professional actors, playing fictional roles, reading a script. As Silver writes, this work points to a complicity on the part of the viewer in his desire to believe and identify with the traditions of and characters on TV. The same television that mimics a perfected form of the identity of the ‘average person’ is also in part responsible for creating this identity; it both researches, uses and manufactures this ‘average person’s‘ hopes and dreams. And so the question of a ‘real person’ becomes ‘real’ compared to what?

results.title: Rhythm
results.brief_description:
Originally planned as a work for Chrysler Corporation’s weekly television program, ‘Rhythm’ presents a montage of the factory workers, machinery and materials on a car production assembly line.
Lye has edited his footage with a staccato feel that he has matched with the percussive music used for the soundtrack.
Although rejected by Chrysler, the film won first prize in the television category in the 1957 New York Art Directors’ Festival but was subsequently disqualified because it had never been broadcast.

results.title: Versifier
results.brief_description:
Gina Czarnecki’s ‘Versifier’ places the viewer alone in a room with nine naked figures.
Varying in age, race and gender, ‘Versifier’s‘ pale figures are without identity or voice, like spectres of people with a hidden past that has occurred long before our arrival. Rearprojected onto a vast screen stretched like skin across the space, these human forms suggest early nineteenth-century museum exhibits: human specimens stripped of protective layers and preserved eternally in a captive vessel.

Currently heading the Electronic Imaging Department at the University of Dundee, Gina Czarnecki works at the intersection of film, video and computer-generated imagery. In describing ‘Versifier’ she explains, ‘I have always loved the cinematic experience and came to realise that I wanted this in an installation environment. There is something about being in the dark in a public space that focuses your eyes and attention onto small details, sounds, people in the space with you or your inner thoughts and solitude.’

Once enclosed within Czarnecki’s installation, the viewer focuses on the exposed
inhabitants. With its confronting interface, Versifier challenges notions of modesty,
candour, embarrassment, fascination. Experiences that we tend to take for granted are offered up for creepily clinical re-examination. Czarnecki has used digital technology to manipulate the figures into disquieting hybrid forms: skin tones are unusually monochromatic, limbs appear disproportionate and distended. The body itself - the medium through which we all experience the world - takes on disturbing new definitions inside the specimen room that is Versifier.

Czarnecki’s mutant characters gesture forward to contemporary anxieties about the looming new frontier of genetic modification, manipulation and experimentation. But they also point backward to personal memories of vulnerability or exposure, and to communal memories of the Holocaust and genocide in which bodies were lined up and exposed in ways that were an affront to all accepted definitions of humanity. In fact, Czarnecki’s disturbing yet beautiful parade calls into question everything - past, present and future - that makes us human in the most basic, naked way.

results.title: Double concerto: a film about the pianist Roger Woodward
results.creator_credit: Angela Catterns, Abstract Productions, Endeavour Film Productions and Hugh Piper
results.brief_description: The star of “Double Concerto” is the brilliant Australian pianist Roger Woodward. His inspiration and fellow musician is the equally brilliant Polish violinist, Wanda Wilkomirska. Together they play the double concerto “Southern Cross”, a concerto written especially for them by Australia’s most internationally acclaimed composer, Barry Conyingham. The film follows Roger and Wanda in rehearsal, in concert and in rambling walks along the sea shores. They discuss their music, their politics and their personal lives.

results.title: Old man: new world
results.brief_description: The life of an Old Man is viewed unfolding before us, jumping like memory through time and through everyday spaces with the blinking quickness of an edit. From shot to shot and from screen to screen, a life re-editing itself. Through the ‘old’ eyes of the central character, we glimpse anew the details of our ordinary world and time.

results.title: Shadow Play [interactive]
results.brief_description: The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows, which visitors can do at the entrance to The Story of the Moving Image.

constellations_primary.name: Shadow play
constellations_primary.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

results.description:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.
description_for_label:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-01. Light and Shadow → MI-01-AV01

results.title: What if Succession was a rom com?
results.material_description: digital screen recording of Limimalist's YouTube post
results.brief_description: HBO’s Succession is a brilliant tragicomedy about how the combination of capital and intergenerational trauma corrupts absolutely – but you wouldn’t know that from the online fanbase. In this video, Liminalist recuts series footage to create a romantic comedy-style trailer about Tom Wambsgans and Greg Hirsch. Through deft editing and a boppy soundtrack, the trailer reframes their jibes and banter as a blossoming romance. Following the series finale, the video went viral thanks to ‘TomGreg shippers’, a subgroup of fans who make content about their loving but sadistic friendship – or theorise that it might be something more.
results.description: HBO’s Succession is a tragicomedy about how capital and intergenerational trauma corrupts – but you wouldn’t know it from the online fanbase. Through editing and a boppy soundtrack, the trailer reframes their banter as a blossoming romance. results.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.creator_credit: Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja
results.credit_line:
Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Script: Courtney Collins with Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Sound: Left of Elephant Sound

Single-channel video

Approx. 5 mins

Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

constellations_primary.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_primary.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.
